text:
Here's my list of feeds. I think the best use of feedreaders is for extremely low-volume sources where I never want to miss a post, so that's what my list has. My 200+ sites generate only a handful of posts per week.

<http://akkartik.name/feeds.xml>

(Though I stopped using a feedreader when Digg Reader died earlier this year. This list may stop getting further updates.)

attachments.fallback:
[May 30th, 2018 12:05 PM] stefanlesser: I was thinking recently that it would be great to have a list of values, sort of a manifesto, not unlike the Agile Manifesto, to at least have a discussion about the values we share, and to find out where we differ. I think a lot of research is opportunistic (and that's not a bad thing), but lacks a big picture of where we want to take this.

Ultimately, it should be something that allows developers of different platforms and languages to unite and at least discover shared values. One other thing we're incredibly good at is building all these silos of different language and platform communities, where we can all re-invent wheels all the time. I think there is a benefit in this language diversity, but it's hard to reap, because these different communities seldom talk to each other.

text:
Hmm, I'm torn. It's possible Dave is a blub programmer [1] or a macho masochist like Robert Martin [2] (he doesn't actually say "sissy" in the post), but I find myself nodding along to this statement:

> ..what will be the limitations of your language? What can’t it do? It won’t be fast enough for certain things. You’re building an abstraction and they’re always leaky, so people will need to know what they can’t do.

Though I don't agree with this part:

> Otherwise they’ll have to learn the lower level details, which defeats the purpose of an easier language.

Knowing how an abstraction works doesn't defeat its purpose. This a classic overuse of the word "abstraction" to take on division-of-labor connotations: <http://akkartik.name/post/libraries>

But it's super important to know the limitations of the tools we use, and this is something most people fail at. The world doesn't really make it easy. We're all competing for attention by over-inflating claims of how easy something will be. Just start using me and all your problems will disappear. I wish we could return to a more innocent world where claims were more restrained. Like the Royal Society or something..

---

Independent of this defense of Dave, I actually tend to be pretty anti-abstraction myself, so this debate is welcome. One possible entry point into my belief system:

<https://lobste.rs/s/zyomiu/what_does_it_mean_design_software_well#c_yvvkwm>

[1] <http://wiki.c2.com/?BlubParadox>
[2] <http://blog.cleancoder.com/uncle-bob/2017/10/04/CodeIsNotTheAnswer.html>

text:
Thanks for linking back to this, <@U8A5MS6R1>! It’s good to see that this Slack is getting a little busier, even if that means it’ll take me a while to catch up.

Consider the manifesto a very early draft for discussion (I think it says that at the top, but just to be safe). It should obviously be a collection of *our* values. I just thought it would be good to get started with something we can iterate on.

attachments.title: The Wrong Abstraction
attachments.text: I've been thinking about the consequences of the "wrong abstraction." &nbsp;My RailsConf 2014 "all the little things" talk included a section where I asserted: > duplication is far cheaper than the wrong abstraction And in the summary, I went on to advise: >

elements.text: Yup!

text: 'Abstraction' is a broad term. Isn't the very notion of 'procedure' or 'data type' an abstraction? What if these are 'wrong abstractions'? I don't know how to think at this level without trading one abstraction for another (e.g. objects/messaging).

elements.text: 'Abstraction' is a broad term. Isn't the very notion of 'procedure' or 'data type' an abstraction? What if these are 'wrong abstractions'? I don't know how to think at this level without trading one abstraction for another (e.g. objects/messaging).

text:
Yup, my post basically said stop using the term except for extracting functions or methods in your own code.
 If you can't easily jump from an interface to its implementation it's not an abstraction.

elements.text:
Yup, my post basically said stop using the term except for extracting functions or methods in your own code.
 If you can't easily jump from an interface to its implementation it's not an abstraction.

text:
My rant on this is that we programmers need to replace our obsession with programming languages with an obsession for runtimes[1]. The runtime is the car, the language is the color of the bumper.

For me the big problem boils down to making it easy to copy code from one codebase to another, and have confidence when you're done that you didn't cause any regressions.

If you can do this, working with multiple runtimes becomes a lot more tractable.

(Avoiding bugs is a separate problem. As is coming up with the ideal architecture for a codebase. Both these seem about as solvable as world peace. But making codebases more malleable seems like the most ambitious problem we can work on that actually may admit a solution.)

[1] This may not be the best thing I've written on the subject, but it's something: <https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=10397026#10397931>

elements.text:

If you can do this, working with multiple runtimes becomes a lot more tractable.

(Avoiding bugs is a separate problem. As is coming up with the ideal architecture for a codebase. Both these seem about as solvable as world peace. But making codebases more malleable seems like the most ambitious problem we can work on that actually may admit a solution.)

[1] This may not be the best thing I've written on the subject, but it's something:

text: Two thoughts on the originally linked post... (1) "Unions are called exclusive containers rather than sum types."  Or alternatives or options or choices. (2) "recipes are always sequences of instructions" Every now and then I revisit concatenative languages.  It's lovely how you can factor out any sequence of words as a new word.  After some play, the disadvantages of the concatenative model usually cure me.

text:
I'm actually using `choice` in my current language draft :slightly_smiling_face:
I don't follow where you're going with the observation on concatenative languages. For better or worse, Mu isn't concatenative. Instructions take operands and there's no stack.
It's been kinda interesting to me that I keep looking at Forth as a way to build a language in very little assembly/machine code, and then keep passing and moving on. I think it's my need for at least some minimal type system.

in my current language draft

It's been kinda interesting to me that I keep looking at Forth as a way to build a language in very little assembly/machine code, and then keep passing and moving on. I think it's my need for at least some minimal type system.
